key_findings: A novel framework integrating Large Language Models into automotive Software Development Lifecycle enables automated C++ code generation for safety-critical systems while maintaining compliance with automotive safety standards through static verification and test-driven development.

The framework implements a feedback-driven pipeline that integrates testing, simulation, and verification processes, ensuring generated code meets safety-critical requirements through iterative refinement with LLM interactions.

Validation through Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) system development demonstrates practical applicability, with the framework successfully generating automotive control software that passes safety and performance criteria in real-world scenarios.

Integration monitoring system performs three critical functions: getdata from carla server, process carla data(), and adddata tostatistics(), with evaluate data() function triggering mathematical validations for behavioral, comfort, and timing requirements.

Comparative benchmarking of multiple LLMs ensures optimal model selection for accuracy and reliability in safety-critical automotive applications, addressing the unique challenges of increasing system complexity and strict regulatory demands in automotive software development.
limitations: Limited evaluation scope with only Adaptive Cruise Control system validation
Dependency on CARLA simulation environment may not capture all real-world automotive scenarios
future_work: Extension to other safety-critical automotive systems beyond ACC
Integration with additional simulation environments for broader validation
problem_addressed: Automating safety-critical automotive software development while ensuring compliance with regulatory standards and managing increasing system complexity
